description: From the Latin causticus (“burning”), from Ancient Greek καυστικός (kaustikós, “burning”), from καυστός (kaustós, “burnt”) +‎ -ικός (-ikós).

adjectives.description: caustic (comparative more caustic, superlative most caustic)

entries.meaning: Capable of burning, corroding or destroying organic tissue.
(of language, etc.) Sharp, bitter, cutting, biting, and sarcastic in a scathing way.
examples: Madame Beck esteemed me learned and blue; Miss Fanshawe, caustic, ironic, and cynical

entries.meaning: Any substance or means which, applied to animal or other organic tissue, burns, corrodes, or destroys it by chemical action; an escharotic.
(optics, computer graphics) The envelope of reflected or refracted rays of light for a given surface or object.
(mathematics) The envelope of reflected or refracted rays for a given curve.
